--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> The only way to know if you've got redundant features would be to 
use
> one of the above approaches, correct?  Has any of this type of
> analysis been done?  That is, how do we know that the champions 
from
> experiments such as double pole-balancing or the robot duels could 
not
> perform as well with 25% or more of their topology removed?
> 

I think this is missing the point, though.  This is exactly the 
perspective I was trying to argue we should change.  The question is 
not whether it could perform as well with 25% less structure, but 
why would we care if it did?  The goal of systems like that, that 
try to prune down at the end of evolution to a small "good" 
solution, is just to find a final solution that looks good.  But the 
point of NEAT is that *every* networks you evaluate over the course 
of all of evolution has a cost.  What's important is that on average 
over all of evolution we are minimizing the space we have to search 
through.  

ken
